members.name: Karlie Kloss
facts: Following her own curiosity, she took a coding class at the Flatiron School, which ignited a passion to see more people with the opportunity to make change using tech. She awarded 21 scholarships are awarded to young people in NYC to learn how to code.
In 2016, she launched Kode With Klossy summer coding camps, awarding 80+ scholarships across 3 camps in LA, NYC and St. Louis
She pivoted curricula, training and programs virtually in the midst of a global pandemic; creating a sustainable, accessible alternative for scholars

members.name: Ada Lovelace
facts: An English mathematician and writer, chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage's proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine.
She is often regarded as the first to recognize the full potential of a computing machine and the first computer programmer.
She was the first to recognize that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation, and created the first algorithm.

members.name: Hedy Lamarr
facts: Co-inventor of frequency-hopping signal technology which prevents torpedo's radio guidance system from being tracked or jammed during WWII.
The frequency-hopping invention has been incorporated into modern-day bluetooth and GPS technologies.

members.name: Reed Hastings
facts: His first job was at Adaptive Technology, where he created a tool for debugging software.
In 1991, he founded his first company, Pure Software, which produced products to troubleshoot software.

In 1997, he co-founded Netflix, offering flat rate movie rental-by-mail to customers in the US by combining two emerging technologies; DVDs, which were much easier to send as mail than VHS-cassettes, and a website from which to order them, instead of a paper catalogue.

members.name: Marc Randolph
facts: A serial entrepreneur who is said to have helped found the U.S. edition of Macworld magazine and the Ordinal computer mail-order businesses MacWarehouse and MicroWarehouse.

In 1997, he co-founded Netflix, offering flat rate movie rental-by-mail to customers in the US by combining two emerging technologies; DVDs, which were much easier to send as mail than VHS-cassettes, and a website from which to order them, instead of a paper catalogue.
His fascination with using computer software to track customers' buying behavior would ultimately inform his decision to create a user interface at Netflix that doubled as a market research platform.

members.name: Rebecca Guber
members.achievement: Pioneer in the development of CS in Argentina
facts: She was fundamental to the success of the early development of information science in Argentina.
co-founded a consultancy firm called Scientific Technical Advisors (ACT), in part to prevent the Institute's lines of research and work from being totally abandoned during Argentina's coup d'etat.

members.name: Cecilia Berdichevsky
facts: She was fundamental to the success of the early development of information science in Argentina.

members.name: Soledad Antelada Toledano
facts: The first female computer systems engineer and researcher in the cyber security division at Berkeley National Lab.
Founder of Girls Can Hack, an organization dedicated to engaging women in the cybersecurity field.

members.name: Ariel Lopez
facts: CEO ofÂ Knac, a skills platform that aims to reinvent the job application for professionals and companies.

members.name: Megan Smith
members.achievement: Chief Technology Officer of the United States
facts: The first female chief technology officer of the U.S. and served in the White House.
She promotes diversity throughout IT workplaces.

members.name: Adele Goldberg
members.achievement: Co-developer of the programming language Smalltalk-80
facts: Developed SIMULA 67 which is a programming setup that overlaps windows on graphic display screens.
Many of the concepts developed by her and her team at PARC became the basis for graphical user interfaces

members.name: George Antheill
facts: Co-inventor of frequency-hopping signal technology which prevents torpedo's radio guidance system from being tracked or jammed during WWII.
The frequency-hopping invention has been incorporated into modern-day bluetooth and GPS technologies.
